name: factorisation of algebraic expressions
explanation: Rewriting algebraic expressions as products of simpler expressions or factors.

name: expressing numbers in prime factorisation form
explanation: Representing a number as a product of prime numbers raised to powers.

name: expressing numbers in scientific notation
explanation: Writing non-zero positive rational numbers in the form a × 10^n where 1 ≤ a < 10 and n is an integer.

name: operations on numbers in scientific notation
explanation: Performing arithmetic operations such as multiplication and division on numbers expressed in scientific notation.

name: rules of indices (exponents)
explanation: Laws governing the manipulation of powers, including product, quotient, power of a power, zero, negative, and fractional exponents.

name: rules of logarithms
explanation: Properties of logarithms including product, quotient, power rules, and change of base formula.

name: complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Representation of complex numbers as a + ib, where a and b are real numbers and i is the imaginary unit.

name: geometric construction of irrational numbers
explanation: Using geometric methods to construct lengths representing irrational numbers such as √2 and √3.

name: proof of irrationality of √2
explanation: A mathematical proof demonstrating that √2 cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers.

name: verification and justification of formulae from number patterns
explanation: Using algebraic reasoning to confirm and explain formulae derived from observed numerical patterns.

name: net of a rectangular solid
explanation: A two-dimensional pattern that can be folded to form the surface of a rectangular solid.

name: net of a cylinder
explanation: A two-dimensional pattern consisting of two circles and a rectangle that can be folded to form a cylinder.

name: net of a prism
explanation: A two-dimensional pattern that can be folded to form the surface of a prism, including triangular-based prisms.

name: net of a cone
explanation: A two-dimensional pattern consisting of a sector of a circle and a circle that can be folded to form a cone.

name: perimeter of a disc
explanation: The length of the boundary of a circular shape, also known as the circumference.

name: perimeter of a triangle
explanation: The total length of the three sides of a triangle.

name: perimeter of a rectangle
explanation: The total length of all four sides of a rectangle.

name: perimeter of a square
explanation: The total length of all four equal sides of a square.

name: perimeter of a parallelogram
explanation: The total length of all four sides of a parallelogram.

name: perimeter of a trapezium
explanation: The total length of all four sides of a trapezium (trapezoid).

name: area of a disc
explanation: The measure of the space enclosed within the boundary of a circle.

name: area of a triangle
explanation: The measure of the space enclosed within a triangle, calculated using base and height or other formulas.

name: area of a rectangle
explanation: The measure of the space enclosed within a rectangle, calculated as length multiplied by width.

name: area of a square
explanation: The measure of the space enclosed within a square, calculated as the side length squared.

name: area of a parallelogram
explanation: The measure of the space enclosed within a parallelogram, calculated as base times height.

name: area of a trapezium
explanation: The measure of the space enclosed within a trapezium, calculated as half the sum of parallel sides times the height.

name: area of a sector of a disc
explanation: The measure of the space enclosed within a sector (a 'slice') of a circle, proportional to the angle of the sector.

name: area estimation of irregular shapes
explanation: Techniques to approximate the area of shapes that do not have standard geometric formulas, often by decomposition or approximation.

name: volume of a rectangular solid
explanation: The measure of the space occupied by a rectangular solid, calculated as length × width × height.

name: volume of a cylinder
explanation: The measure of the space occupied by a cylinder, calculated as the area of the base circle times the height.

name: volume of a sphere
explanation: The measure of the space occupied by a sphere, calculated using the formula 4/3 π r³.

name: volume of a hemisphere
explanation: The measure of the space occupied by half a sphere, calculated as half the volume of a sphere.

name: volume of a right cone
explanation: The measure of the space occupied by a right circular cone, calculated as one-third the area of the base times the height.

name: volume of a triangular-based prism
explanation: The measure of the space occupied by a prism with a triangular base, calculated as the area of the triangular base times the length of the prism.

name: surface area of a rectangular solid
explanation: The total area of all the faces of a rectangular solid.

name: surface area of a cylinder
explanation: The total area of the curved surface and the two circular bases of a cylinder.

name: surface area of a sphere
explanation: The total area covering the surface of a sphere, calculated as 4 π r².

name: surface area of a hemisphere
explanation: The total area covering the curved surface and the base of a hemisphere.

name: surface area of a right cone
explanation: The total area of the curved surface and the base of a right circular cone.

name: surface area of a triangular-based prism
explanation: The total area of all faces of a prism with a triangular base.

name: trapezoidal rule for area approximation
explanation: A numerical method to approximate the area under a curve by dividing it into trapezoids and summing their areas.

name: relationship between circumference and diameter of a circle
explanation: The constant ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter, known as π (pi).

name: drawing and interpreting scaled diagrams
explanation: Creating and understanding diagrams where all lengths are proportionally reduced or enlarged by a scale factor.

name: percentage calculation
explanation: Calculating the percentage value of a quantity, including finding a percentage of a number and converting between fractions, decimals, and percentages.

name: percentage profit and loss calculation
explanation: Determining profit or loss as a percentage of the cost price, including calculating selling price, discount, and mark up.

name: compound interest calculation (up to 3 years)
explanation: Calculating the amount of compound interest accrued on an investment or loan over a period not exceeding three years.

name: income tax calculation (standard rate only)
explanation: Computing income tax payable at a standard rate based on given income and deductions.

name: net pay calculation including deductions
explanation: Calculating the net pay of an individual after subtracting specified deductions such as taxes and other contributions.

name: ratio and proportion problem solving
explanation: Using the equivalence of ratios and proportions to solve problems involving comparison and scaling of quantities.

name: rounding numerical results
explanation: Rounding numerical answers to a specified degree of accuracy or decimal place.

name: checking results by working backwards
explanation: Verifying the correctness of a solution by reversing the steps of the calculation.

name: calculating average speed from distance and time
explanation: Determining average speed by dividing total distance traveled by total time taken.

name: calculating distance from average speed and time
explanation: Finding the distance traveled by multiplying average speed by time.

name: calculating time from distance and average speed
explanation: Determining the time taken by dividing distance by average speed.

name: calculating percentage error
explanation: Computing the percentage difference between an approximate or measured value and the exact or true value.

name: calculating tolerance in measurements
explanation: Determining the allowable deviation from a specified measurement value.

name: accumulating error by addition or subtraction
explanation: Understanding how errors in measurements or calculations combine when quantities are added or subtracted.

name: using present value in loan repayments and investments
explanation: Calculating the current worth of a future sum of money or stream of cash flows given a specified rate of return.

name: Equation solving and manipulation
explanation: Techniques and processes used to find values of variables that satisfy algebraic equations.

name: Limits of sequences
explanation: The value that the terms of a sequence approach as the index goes to infinity.

name: Financial mathematics applications
explanation: Applying mathematical concepts such as compound interest, income tax, net pay, and mortgage repayments to real-world financial problems.

name: Depreciation (reducing balance method)
explanation: Calculating the decrease in value of an asset over time using a fixed percentage rate applied to the reducing balance.

name: Metric and imperial unit conversions
explanation: Converting measurements between metric and imperial units using conversion factors.

name: Costing including materials, labour, and wastage
explanation: Calculating total cost by considering costs of materials, labour, and wastage in production or projects.

name: Average rate of change
explanation: Calculating the average rate at which a quantity changes with respect to another variable, often time.

name: polynomial expression
explanation: An algebraic expression formed by the addition of terms with variables raised to positive integer powers and coefficients.

name: binomial expression
explanation: A polynomial expression containing exactly two terms.

name: trinomial expression
explanation: A polynomial expression containing exactly three terms.

name: degree of a polynomial
explanation: The highest power of the variable in a polynomial expression.

name: coefficient of a term in a polynomial
explanation: The numerical factor multiplying the variable term in a polynomial expression.

name: addition and subtraction of polynomial expressions
explanation: Combining like terms by adding or subtracting their coefficients.

name: multiplying polynomial expressions (expanding)
explanation: Using the distributive law to multiply polynomials by multiplying each term in one polynomial by each term in the other.

name: perfect square polynomial
explanation: A polynomial that can be expressed as the square of a binomial, e.g., (x + a)^2 = x^2 + 2ax + a^2.

name: difference of two squares
explanation: A binomial expression of the form a^2 - b^2 which factors as (a - b)(a + b).

name: dividing algebraic expressions by a monomial
explanation: Dividing each term of the numerator polynomial by the monomial denominator.

name: dividing algebraic expressions by a polynomial factor
explanation: Dividing a polynomial numerator by a polynomial denominator that is a factor, simplifying the expression.

name: polynomial long division
explanation: A method to divide polynomials when the denominator is not a factor, similar to numerical long division.

name: polynomial function
explanation: A function defined by a polynomial expression, where the output depends on the input variable.

name: evaluating polynomial functions
explanation: Calculating the value of a polynomial function by substituting a given value for the variable and simplifying.

name: finding the domain restrictions of polynomial functions
explanation: Determining the set of input values for which the polynomial function is defined, e.g., ensuring denominators are non-zero.

name: finding the volume and surface area functions of geometric solids
explanation: Expressing volume and surface area as polynomial functions of dimensions, e.g., box dimensions depending on variable x.

name: factorising algebraic expressions by highest common factor
explanation: Extracting the greatest common monomial factor from all terms of an algebraic expression.

name: factorising by grouping
explanation: Grouping terms in pairs or sets to factor out common factors and then factorising the resulting expression.

name: factorising difference of two squares
explanation: Expressing a^2 - b^2 as (a - b)(a + b).

name: factorising quadratic expressions by trial and error
explanation: Finding two binomial factors of a quadratic expression by testing factor pairs of the constant term.

name: factorising quadratic expressions using the quadratic formula
explanation: Using the roots found by the quadratic formula to write the quadratic as a product of two linear factors.

name: factorising sum and difference of cubes
explanation: Expressing x^3 - y^3 as (x - y)(x^2 + xy + y^2) and x^3 + y^3 as (x + y)(x^2 - xy + y^2).

name: simplifying algebraic fractions
explanation: Reducing algebraic fractions by factorising numerator and denominator and cancelling common factors.

name: adding and subtracting algebraic fractions
explanation: Finding a common denominator and combining numerators accordingly.

name: multiplying and dividing algebraic fractions
explanation: Multiplying numerators and denominators separately; dividing by multiplying by reciprocal.

name: binomial expansion using Pascal's triangle
explanation: Expanding (a + b)^n using coefficients from Pascal's triangle and powers of a and b.

name: binomial theorem general term
explanation: The r-th term in the expansion of (a + b)^n is given by C(n, r) a^{n-r} b^r.

name: algebraic identities
explanation: Equations true for all values of the variable, often used to find unknown coefficients or simplify expressions.

name: partial fraction decomposition using algebraic identities
explanation: Expressing a rational function as a sum of simpler fractions using algebraic identities and solving for unknown coefficients.

name: manipulating formulae to make a variable the subject
explanation: Rearranging equations to express one variable explicitly in terms of others.

name: solving linear equations
explanation: Finding the value(s) of the variable(s) that satisfy a linear equation.

name: solving quadratic equations by factorisation
explanation: Solving quadratic equations by expressing them as a product of factors equal to zero and finding roots.

name: solving quadratic equations by quadratic formula
explanation: Using the quadratic formula to find roots of any quadratic equation.

name: solving quadratic equations by substitution
explanation: Using substitution to reduce complex equations to quadratic form and then solving.

name: discriminant and nature of quadratic roots
explanation: Using the discriminant b^2 - 4ac to determine whether roots are real distinct, real equal, or complex.

name: forming quadratic equations from roots
explanation: Constructing a quadratic equation given its roots using the relation x^2 - (sum of roots)x + product of roots = 0.

name: completing the square
explanation: Rewriting a quadratic expression in the form a(x - p)^2 + q to find vertex, minimum/maximum values, and solve equations.

name: simplifying surds
explanation: Reducing square roots to simplest form by factoring out perfect squares and rationalising denominators.

name: distance formula between two points in coordinate plane
explanation: Calculates the length of the line segment between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) using the formula sqrt((x2 - x1)^2 + (y2 - y1)^2).

name: midpoint formula of a line segment
explanation: Finds the point exactly halfway between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) using the formula ((x1 + x2)/2, (y1 + y2)/2).

name: slope of a line segment
explanation: Measures the steepness or incline of a line segment between two points, calculated as (y2 - y1) / (x2 - x1).

name: condition for parallel lines in coordinate geometry
explanation: Two lines are parallel if and only if their slopes are equal.

name: condition for perpendicular lines in coordinate geometry
explanation: Two lines are perpendicular if and only if the product of their slopes is -1.

name: equation of a line in slope-intercept form
explanation: Represents a line as y = mx + c, where m is the slope and c is the y-intercept.

name: equation of a line through a point with given slope
explanation: The line passing through (x1, y1) with slope m is given by y - y1 = m(x - x1).

name: angle between two lines using slopes
explanation: The angle θ between two lines with slopes m1 and m2 satisfies tan θ = |(m1 - m2) / (1 + m1 m2)|.

name: internal division of a line segment in a given ratio
explanation: The point dividing the segment between (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) internally in ratio a:b has coordinates ((b x1 + a x2)/(a + b), (b y1 + a y2)/(a + b)).

name: median of a triangle
explanation: A line segment joining a vertex of a triangle to the midpoint of the opposite side.

name: centroid of a triangle
explanation: The point of concurrency of the three medians of a triangle; coordinates are the average of the vertices' coordinates.

name: circumcentre of a triangle
explanation: The point of concurrency of the perpendicular bisectors of the sides of a triangle; center of the circumscribed circle.

name: orthocentre of a triangle
explanation: The point of concurrency of the altitudes (perpendiculars from vertices to opposite sides) of a triangle.

name: equation of a circle with centre at origin
explanation: The set of points (x, y) at distance r from (0,0) satisfy x^2 + y^2 = r^2.

name: equation of a circle with centre not at origin
explanation: The set of points (x, y) at distance r from (h, k) satisfy (x - h)^2 + (y - k)^2 = r^2.

name: general form of circle equation
explanation: Circle equation expressed as x^2 + y^2 + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0, with centre (-g, -f) and radius sqrt(g^2 + f^2 - c).

name: condition for a point to lie inside, on, or outside a circle
explanation: Point P lies inside if distance to centre < radius, on if equal, outside if greater.

name: perpendicular bisector of a chord contains the centre of the circle
explanation: The centre of a circle lies on the perpendicular bisector of any chord.

name: perpendicular from centre to chord bisects the chord
explanation: The line from the centre of a circle perpendicular to a chord divides the chord into two equal parts.

name: tangent to a circle is perpendicular to radius at point of contact
explanation: The tangent line to a circle at point P is perpendicular to the radius drawn to P.

name: equation of tangent to circle at a point
explanation: The tangent line at point P(x1, y1) on circle with centre (h, k) has slope negative reciprocal of radius slope and passes through P.

name: length of tangent from a point to a circle
explanation: Length of tangent from point P to circle with centre O and radius r is sqrt(|OP|^2 - r^2).

name: points of intersection of a line and a circle
explanation: Solutions to simultaneous equations of line and circle give points of intersection; one solution means tangent, two solutions means secant.

name: common chord of two circles
explanation: The line passing through the intersection points of two circles, found by subtracting their equations.

name: condition for two circles to touch externally
explanation: Two circles touch externally if distance between centres equals sum of radii.

name: condition for two circles to touch internally
explanation: Two circles touch internally if distance between centres equals difference of radii.

name: line drawn parallel to one side of triangle divides other sides proportionally
explanation: A line parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two sides in the same ratio.

name: three parallel lines cut equal segments on any transversal
explanation: If three parallel lines cut equal segments on one transversal, they cut equal segments on any other transversal.

name: similar triangles side proportionality
explanation: If two triangles are similar, corresponding sides are in proportion.

name: basic trigonometric ratios
explanation: Definitions of sine, cosine, and tangent as ratios of sides in a right-angled triangle.

name: exact trigonometric ratios for 30°, 45°, 60°
explanation: Sine, cosine, and tangent values for 30°, 45°, and 60° expressed as fractions or surds.

name: unit circle coordinates as (cos θ, sin θ)
explanation: Any point on the unit circle can be represented as (cos θ, sin θ), where θ is the angle from the positive x-axis.

name: signs of trigonometric ratios in four quadrants
explanation: Determines which of sine, cosine, and tangent are positive or negative in each quadrant of the coordinate plane.

name: radian measure
explanation: A radian is the measure of an angle at the center of a circle subtended by an arc equal in length to the radius.

name: conversion between degrees and radians
explanation: The process of converting angle measures from degrees to radians and vice versa using the relationships 2π radians = 360° and π radians = 180°.

name: arc length formula
explanation: The length of an arc of a circle is given by l = rθ, where r is the radius and θ is the central angle in radians.

name: area of sector formula
explanation: The area of a sector of a circle is given by (1/2) r² θ, where r is the radius and θ is the central angle in radians.

name: basic trigonometric ratios in right-angled triangles
explanation: Definitions of sine, cosine, and tangent as ratios of sides in a right-angled triangle: sin A = opposite/hypotenuse, cos A = adjacent/hypotenuse, tan A = opposite/adjacent.

name: calculator use for trigonometric ratios
explanation: Using calculator functions to find sine, cosine, tangent values and their inverses for given angles or ratios.

name: special angle trigonometric values
explanation: Exact sine, cosine, and tangent values for 30°, 45°, and 60° angles expressed as fractions or surds.

name: unit circle coordinates for sine and cosine
explanation: Any point on the unit circle has coordinates (cos θ, sin θ), relating angles to trigonometric ratios.

name: signs of trigonometric ratios in quadrants
explanation: Determining the positive or negative signs of sine, cosine, and tangent in each of the four quadrants of the coordinate plane.

name: reference angle concept
explanation: The reference angle is the acute angle between the terminal side of an angle and the x-axis, used to find trigonometric values for angles in any quadrant.

name: sine rule for any triangle
explanation: The relationship between sides and angles in any triangle: a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C.

name: ambiguous case of sine rule
explanation: The situation in the sine rule where two different triangles satisfy the given conditions, typically when two sides and a non-included angle are known.

name: area of triangle using sine
explanation: Area of a triangle = (1/2) * product of two sides * sine of included angle.

name: cosine rule for any triangle
explanation: Relates the lengths of sides of a triangle to the cosine of one angle: a² = b² + c² - 2bc cos A.

name: graph of sine function
explanation: Plotting y = sin x over [0, 2π], showing periodicity with period 2π and range [-1,1].

name: graph of cosine function
explanation: Plotting y = cos x over [0, 2π], showing periodicity with period 2π and range [-1,1].

name: graph of tangent function
explanation: Plotting y = tan x showing periodicity with period π, vertical asymptotes at odd multiples of π/2, and range all real numbers.

name: amplitude of trigonometric function
explanation: The amplitude of y = b sin x or y = b cos x is |b|, representing the maximum displacement from the midline.

name: period of trigonometric function
explanation: The period of y = sin (c x) or y = cos (c x) is 2π / c, the length over which the function repeats.

name: vertical translation of trigonometric graph
explanation: Adding a constant a to y = b sin (c x) or y = b cos (c x) shifts the graph vertically by a units, changing the midline to y = a.

name: general solution of trigonometric equations
explanation: The set of all solutions to equations like sin x = k or cos x = k, expressed as x = principal solutions + n * period, where n is any integer.

name: sum and difference formulae for sine
explanation: sin (A ± B) = sin A cos B ± cos A sin B, expressing sine of sum or difference of angles.

name: sum and difference formulae for cosine
explanation: cos (A ± B) = cos A cos B ∓ sin A sin B, expressing cosine of sum or difference of angles.

name: sum and difference formulae for tangent
explanation: tan (A ± B) = (tan A ± tan B) / (1 ∓ tan A tan B), expressing tangent of sum or difference of angles.

name: product to sum and sum to product trigonometric identities
explanation: Formulas that convert products of sine and cosine into sums or differences and vice versa, e.g., 2 sin A cos B = sin (A+B) + sin (A-B).

name: inverse sine function
explanation: The function sin⁻¹ x gives the angle whose sine is x, defined on [-1,1] with range [-π/2, π/2].

name: inverse cosine function
explanation: The function cos⁻¹ x gives the angle whose cosine is x, defined on [-1,1] with range [0, π].

name: inverse tangent function
explanation: The function tan⁻¹ x gives the angle whose tangent is x, defined on all real numbers with range (-π/2, π/2).

name: discrete data
explanation: Data that can take only certain individual values, often counts of items or events.

name: continuous data
explanation: Data that can take any value within a range, often measurements on a scale.

name: categorical data
explanation: Data that fits into categories or groups rather than numerical values.

name: nominal categorical data
explanation: Categorical data where categories have no natural order, e.g., colours or gender.

name: ordinal categorical data
explanation: Categorical data where categories have a natural order, e.g., rankings or ratings.

name: primary data
explanation: Data collected firsthand by the researcher for a specific purpose.

name: secondary data
explanation: Data collected by someone else for a different purpose, used by the researcher.

name: univariate data
explanation: Data consisting of observations on a single variable.

name: bivariate data
explanation: Data consisting of paired observations on two variables.

name: mode of a data set
explanation: The value that occurs most frequently in a data set.

name: mean of a data set
explanation: The sum of all data values divided by the number of values; the average.

name: mean of a frequency distribution
explanation: The weighted average calculated by multiplying each value by its frequency, summing, and dividing by total frequency.

name: estimated mean from grouped frequency distribution
explanation: An estimate of the mean found by using mid-interval values of class intervals multiplied by frequencies.

name: median of a data set
explanation: The middle value when data is ordered; if even number of values, the average of the two middle values.

name: median of a frequency distribution
explanation: The value corresponding to the middle cumulative frequency in ordered data.

name: lower quartile (Q1)
explanation: The value below which 25% of the data lies; the 25th percentile.

name: upper quartile (Q3)
explanation: The value below which 75% of the data lies; the 75th percentile.

name: interquartile range
explanation: The difference between the upper and lower quartiles; measures spread of the middle 50% of data.

name: standard deviation of a data set
explanation: A measure of spread indicating the average distance of data points from the mean.

name: standard deviation of a frequency distribution
explanation: Calculated by weighting squared deviations from the mean by frequencies, summing, dividing by total frequency, and taking the square root.

name: percentile
explanation: A value below which a given percentage of data falls; e.g., 40th percentile is the value below which 40% of data lies.

name: stem and leaf diagram
explanation: A graphical method of displaying data where the stem represents leading digits and leaves represent trailing digits, preserving original data values.

name: back-to-back stem and leaf diagram
explanation: A comparative graphical display where two stem and leaf diagrams share the same stem, with leaves on opposite sides for two data sets.

name: histogram with equal class intervals
explanation: A bar graph representing frequency distribution of continuous data with adjacent bars and equal width intervals; area of bars proportional to frequency.

name: modal class in histogram
explanation: The class interval with the highest frequency in a histogram.

name: skewness of distribution
explanation: A measure of asymmetry in a distribution; positive skew has a long tail to the right, negative skew has a long tail to the left.

name: symmetrical distribution
explanation: A distribution where data is evenly spread around the center, with mean, median and mode approximately equal.

name: bimodal distribution
explanation: A distribution with two distinct modes or peaks.

name: Fundamental principle of counting
explanation: If one task can be accomplished in m ways and a second task in n ways, then the two tasks together can be accomplished in m × n ways.

name: Permutation of n distinct objects
explanation: The number of ways to arrange n distinct objects in order is n! (n factorial).

name: Permutation of n objects taken r at a time
explanation: Number of ordered arrangements of r objects chosen from n distinct objects, given by P(n, r) = n! / (n - r)!

name: Combination of n objects taken r at a time
explanation: Number of unordered selections of r objects from n distinct objects, given by C(n, r) = n! / (r! (n - r)!)

name: Complementary event probability
explanation: The probability that event E does not occur is 1 minus the probability that E occurs, i.e., P(E') = 1 - P(E).

name: Sample space
explanation: The set of all possible outcomes of a probability experiment.

name: Mutually exclusive events
explanation: Events that cannot occur simultaneously; for such events A and B, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B).

name: Addition rule for non-mutually exclusive events
explanation: For events A and B that can occur together, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B).

name: Exhaustive events
explanation: A set of events that cover all possible outcomes; their probabilities sum to 1.

name: Conditional probability
explanation: The probability of event A occurring given that event B has occurred, denoted P(A|B) = P(A and B) / P(B).

name: Multiplication law for independent events
explanation: For independent events A and B, the probability that both occur is P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B).

name: Experimental probability (relative frequency)
explanation: An estimate of probability based on the ratio of the number of successful trials to the total number of trials.

name: Sample space for two independent events
explanation: The set of all ordered pairs of outcomes from two independent experiments, e.g., tossing two coins.

name: Finding probability from a sample space
explanation: Calculating probability by counting the number of favorable outcomes divided by total outcomes in the sample space.

name: average rate of change of a function over an interval
explanation: The average rate of change of a function y=f(x) over the interval [a,b] is the slope of the secant line joining the points (a,f(a)) and (b,f(b)), calculated as (f(b)-f(a))/(b-a).

name: limit of a function as x approaches a finite value
explanation: The value that the function f(x) approaches as x tends to a specific value a, denoted lim_{x→a} f(x).

name: indeterminate form 0/0 in limits
explanation: A limit expression that results in 0/0 upon direct substitution, requiring algebraic manipulation such as factorization to evaluate the limit.

name: limit of a function as x approaches infinity
explanation: The value that the function f(x) approaches as x tends to infinity, often found by dividing numerator and denominator by the highest power of x.

name: differentiation from first principles
explanation: The process of finding the derivative of a function f(x) by evaluating the limit of the difference quotient (f(x+h)-f(x))/h as h approaches zero.

name: power rule for differentiation
explanation: The rule that the derivative of y = x^n is dy/dx = n x^{n-1} for any real number n.

name: derivative of a constant function
explanation: The derivative of a constant function y = c is zero, since the function has zero rate of change.

name: sum and difference rule for derivatives
explanation: The derivative of a sum or difference of functions is the sum or difference of their derivatives.

name: derivative of reciprocal powers
explanation: To differentiate functions like y = 1/x^n, rewrite as y = x^{-n} and apply the power rule.

name: product rule for differentiation
explanation: If y = u(x) * v(x), then dy/dx = u * dv/dx + v * du/dx.

name: quotient rule for differentiation
explanation: If y = u(x)/v(x), then dy/dx = (v * du/dx - u * dv/dx) / v^2.

name: chain rule for differentiation
explanation: If y = f(g(x)), then dy/dx = f'(g(x)) * g'(x).

name: derivative of sine function
explanation: The derivative of sin x with respect to x is cos x.

name: derivative of cosine function
explanation: The derivative of cos x with respect to x is -sin x.

name: derivative of tangent function
explanation: The derivative of tan x with respect to x is sec^2 x.

name: derivative of inverse sine function
explanation: If y = sin^{-1}(x/a), then dy/dx = 1 / sqrt(a^2 - x^2).

name: derivative of inverse tangent function
explanation: If y = tan^{-1}(x/a), then dy/dx = a / (a^2 + x^2).

name: derivative of inverse cosine function
explanation: If y = cos^{-1}(x/a), then dy/dx = -1 / sqrt(a^2 - x^2).

name: derivative of exponential function e^x
explanation: The derivative of e^x with respect to x is e^x.

name: derivative of exponential function e^{ax}
explanation: If y = e^{ax}, then dy/dx = a e^{ax}.

name: derivative of logarithmic function ln x
explanation: The derivative of ln x with respect to x is 1/x.

name: derivative of logarithmic function ln f(x)
explanation: If y = ln(f(x)), then dy/dx = f'(x)/f(x).

name: second derivative of a function
explanation: The derivative of the first derivative of a function, denoted d^2y/dx^2 or f''(x), representing the rate of change of the slope.

name: trigonometric identity cos^2 θ + sin^2 θ = 1
explanation: Fundamental identity relating the squares of sine and cosine of the same angle, true for all θ.

name: compound angle formula for cosine
explanation: Formula expressing cos(A ± B) in terms of cos A, cos B, sin A, and sin B: cos(A ± B) = cos A cos B ∓ sin A sin B.

name: compound angle formula for sine
explanation: Formula expressing sin(A ± B) in terms of sin A, cos B, cos A, and sin B: sin(A ± B) = sin A cos B ± cos A sin B.

name: compound angle formula for tangent
explanation: Formula expressing tan(A ± B) in terms of tan A and tan B: tan(A ± B) = (tan A ± tan B) / (1 ∓ tan A tan B).

name: sum to infinity of a geometric series with |r|<1
explanation: The sum to infinity of a geometric series with common ratio |r|<1 is S_infinity = a / (1 - r).

name: equation of a tangent to a circle
explanation: The linear equation of the tangent line to a circle at a given point on the circle, found using the slope of the radius and point-slope form.

name: perpendicular bisector of a chord
explanation: The line perpendicular to a chord of a circle that passes through the midpoint of the chord and contains the centre of the circle.

name: common tangent of two circles
explanation: A line that touches two circles at exactly one point each, either externally or internally.

name: modulus (absolute value) function
explanation: A function that returns the non-negative value of a number or expression, denoted by |x|.

name: modular equations and inequalities
explanation: Equations and inequalities involving modulus expressions, solved by considering positive and negative cases or squaring.

name: proof by contradiction
explanation: A method of mathematical proof where assuming the negation of a statement leads to a contradiction, proving the original statement true.

name: proof by induction
explanation: A method of proof for statements involving natural numbers, proving the base case and then the inductive step to establish truth for all natural numbers.

name: direct proof
explanation: A method of proof using axioms, definitions, and previously proven theorems to establish the truth of a statement.

name: abstract inequalities
explanation: Inequalities involving algebraic expressions with variables, proven using algebraic manipulation and properties of squares.

name: proofs of divisibility
explanation: Mathematical proofs showing that expressions are divisible by a given number for all natural numbers, often using induction.

name: exponential growth and decay models
explanation: Mathematical models describing quantities that increase or decrease exponentially over time, using functions of the form A·a^x or A·e^{bx}.

name: doubling time
explanation: The time required for an exponentially growing quantity to double in size, calculated using logarithms and growth constants.

name: logarithmic equations
explanation: Equations involving logarithms, solved by applying log laws, changing bases, and converting to exponential form.

name: laws of logarithms
explanation: Fundamental properties of logarithms including product, quotient, power, and change of base rules.

name: inverse trigonometric functions
explanation: Functions that give the angle whose sine, cosine, or tangent is a given value, denoted sin^{-1}, cos^{-1}, tan^{-1}.

name: recurrence relations
explanation: Definitions of sequences where each term is defined as a function of previous terms.

name: finite difference method
explanation: A method to identify the degree of a polynomial sequence by examining successive differences of terms.

name: sigma notation for series
explanation: A concise notation using the summation symbol Σ to represent the sum of terms in a sequence.

name: percentiles
explanation: Values dividing a data set into 100 equal parts, indicating the relative standing of a data point.

name: outliers
explanation: Data points that are significantly different from other observations, affecting measures like mean and standard deviation.

name: explanatory and response variables
explanation: In experiments, the explanatory variable is controlled or manipulated, and the response variable is observed for changes.

name: sampling methods
explanation: Techniques for selecting representative samples from populations, including simple random, stratified, systematic, quota, cluster, and convenience sampling.

name: Basic geometry (points, lines, triangles)
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Basic geometry (points, lines, triangles)

name: Using slope to determine parallel and perpendicular lines
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Using slope to determine parallel and perpendicular lines

name: Concurrencies of a triangle (centroid, circumcentre, orthocentre)
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Concurrencies of a triangle (centroid, circumcentre, orthocentre)

name: Solving cubic equations
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Solving cubic equations

name: Algebraic surd equations
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Algebraic surd equations

name: natural numbers
explanation: The set of whole positive numbers starting from 1, i.e., {1, 2, 3, ...}.

name: integers
explanation: The set of whole numbers including positive, negative numbers and zero, i.e., {..., -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, ...}.

name: rational numbers
explanation: Numbers that can be expressed as a ratio of two integers a/b where b ≠ 0, including fractions and decimals that terminate or repeat.

name: irrational numbers
explanation: Real numbers that cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers; their decimal expansions are non-terminating and non-repeating.

name: surd simplification
explanation: The process of expressing an irrational square root in simplest form by factoring out perfect squares, e.g., √18 = 3√2.

name: constructing line segment of length √2
explanation: Using compass and straightedge to construct a line segment on the number line whose length is the square root of 2.

name: constructing line segment of length √3
explanation: Using compass and straightedge to construct a line segment on the number line whose length is the square root of 3.

name: imaginary unit i
explanation: The imaginary number defined as i = √(-1), used to extend the real number system to complex numbers.

name: imaginary numbers
explanation: Numbers of the form bi where b is a real number and i = √(-1), representing square roots of negative numbers.

name: subtraction of complex numbers
explanation: Subtracting complex numbers by separately subtracting their real parts and imaginary parts.

name: division of complex numbers using conjugates
explanation: Dividing complex numbers by multiplying numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator to rationalize it.

name: equality of complex numbers
explanation: Two complex numbers are equal if and only if their real parts are equal and their imaginary parts are equal.

name: powers of i
explanation: The cyclic pattern of powers of i: i¹ = i, i² = -1, i³ = -i, i⁴ = 1, repeating every 4 powers.

name: Argand diagram
explanation: A geometric representation of complex numbers as points in the plane with real part on x-axis and imaginary part on y-axis.

name: geometric interpretation of complex addition
explanation: Adding complex numbers corresponds to vector addition in the Argand plane, resulting in translation.

name: geometric interpretation of multiplication by real scalar
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by a real number scales its modulus and stretches or contracts it from the origin.

name: geometric interpretation of multiplication by i
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by i corresponds to a rotation by 90 degrees counterclockwise about the origin in the Argand plane.

name: transformations of complex numbers
explanation: Operations such as scaling, rotation, reflection, and translation represented by multiplication and addition of complex numbers.

name: conjugate roots theorem
explanation: If a polynomial with real coefficients has a complex root z, then its conjugate z̄ is also a root.

name: polar form of a complex number
explanation: Representation of a complex number as z = r(cos θ + i sin θ), where r is modulus and θ is argument (angle).

name: argument of a complex number
explanation: The angle θ between the positive real axis and the line representing the complex number in the Argand plane.

name: conversion between rectangular and polar forms
explanation: Using trigonometric relations: x = r cos θ, y = r sin θ, to convert between forms of complex numbers.

name: multiplication of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: Multiplying moduli and adding arguments: z₁z₂ = r₁r₂ [cos(θ₁ + θ₂) + i sin(θ₁ + θ₂)].

name: division of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: Dividing moduli and subtracting arguments: z₁/z₂ = (r₁/r₂) [cos(θ₁ - θ₂) + i sin(θ₁ - θ₂)].

name: de Moivre's theorem
explanation: For integer n, (cos θ + i sin θ)^n = cos nθ + i sin nθ, used to compute powers and roots of complex numbers.

name: nth roots of complex numbers using de Moivre's theorem
explanation: Finding nth roots by expressing complex number in polar form and applying de Moivre's theorem with general argument θ + 2πk.

name: expressing trigonometric functions of multiple angles using de Moivre's theorem
explanation: Using de Moivre's theorem to express cos nθ and sin nθ in terms of powers of cos θ and sin θ.

name: irrational number
explanation: A real number that cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers, characterized by non-terminating, non-repeating decimal expansions.

name: simplifying surds by factorization
explanation: The process of expressing a surd in simplest form by factoring out perfect squares from under the radical sign.

name: construction of line segment of length sqrt(2) using compass and straightedge
explanation: A geometric construction method to create a line segment of length √2 on the number line using perpendicular bisectors and arcs.

name: square root of a complex number in rectangular form
explanation: Expressing the square root of a complex number as a + bi by solving simultaneous equations derived from squaring a + bi.

name: geometric interpretation of complex number addition
explanation: Adding complex numbers corresponds to vector addition in the Argand plane, resulting in translation.

name: geometric interpretation of complex number multiplication by a real scalar
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by a real number scales its modulus, resulting in stretching or contraction from the origin.

name: geometric interpretation of complex number multiplication by i
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by i corresponds to a rotation of 90 degrees counterclockwise about the origin in the Argand plane.

name: conversion between rectangular and polar forms of complex numbers
explanation: Using trigonometric relations to convert between x + iy and r(cos θ + i sin θ) forms.

name: antidifferentiation (indefinite integration) of power functions
explanation: Finding the general antiderivative of x^n as x^{n+1}/(n+1) + c, reversing differentiation.

name: constant of integration
explanation: An arbitrary constant added to the indefinite integral representing the family of antiderivatives.

name: integration of exponential functions
explanation: Integrating e^{ax} as (1/a) e^{ax} + c and a^{x} as a^{x}/ln a + c.

name: integration of trigonometric functions
explanation: Integrals of sin(ax) and cos(ax) as -cos(ax)/a + c and sin(ax)/a + c respectively.

name: application of integration to kinematics
explanation: Using integration to find velocity from acceleration and displacement from velocity functions.

name: definite integral as area under a curve
explanation: Calculating the exact area between a curve and the x-axis over an interval using definite integrals.

name: area between two curves
explanation: Finding the area enclosed between two curves by integrating the difference of their functions over the interval.

name: average value of a function over an interval
explanation: The average value of f(x) over [a,b] is (1/(b−a)) ∫_a^b f(x) dx, representing the height of a rectangle with equal area.

name: rate of change
explanation: The derivative representing the instantaneous rate of change of one quantity with respect to another, often time.

name: related rates of change
explanation: Using the chain rule to relate rates of change of related variables with respect to time.

name: compound interest formula
explanation: Calculating the final amount F = P(1 + i)^t for principal P invested at interest rate i for t periods.

name: present value formula
explanation: Calculating the present value as PV = F / (1 + i)^t for future amount F discounted at rate i over t periods.

name: reducing balance depreciation
explanation: Depreciation method where the asset value decreases by a fixed percentage each period: F = P(1 - i)^t.

name: instalment savings (annuities) final value formula
explanation: Sum of geometric series representing accumulated value of regular payments: F = P(1+i)[(1+i)^t - 1]/i.

name: pension present value formula
explanation: Present value of a series of future payments: PV = P/(1+i) * [1 - (1/(1+i))^t] / [1 - 1/(1+i)].

name: loan repayment formula
explanation: Monthly repayment A = P * [i(1+i)^t] / [(1+i)^t - 1] for loan amount P, interest rate i, and t payments.

name: tree diagram for probability
explanation: A branching diagram representing all possible outcomes of sequential events with associated probabilities.

name: probability distribution of a discrete random variable
explanation: A table or function listing possible values of a discrete random variable and their associated probabilities.

name: expected value of a discrete random variable
explanation: The weighted average of all possible values of the variable, calculated as sum of x * P(x).

name: binomial distribution probability formula
explanation: Probability of r successes in n independent Bernoulli trials: P(r) = C(n,r) p^r q^{n-r}.

name: conversion between rectangular and polar form of complex numbers
explanation: Using trigonometric relations to convert between a + bi and r(cos θ + i sin θ).

name: simplifying expressions of the form (cos θ - i sin θ)^n
explanation: Using the identity cos θ - i sin θ = cos(-θ) + i sin(-θ) and applying de Moivre's theorem accordingly.

name: integration of sums and constant multiples
explanation: Integral of sum is sum of integrals; constants can be factored out of integrals.

name: integration by substitution (chain rule in reverse)
explanation: Integrating functions of the form f(g(x)) g'(x) dx by substituting u = g(x).

name: definite integration to find area under a curve
explanation: Calculating the exact area between a curve y=f(x) and the x-axis between x=a and x=b using ∫_a^b f(x) dx.

name: finding area using trapezoidal rule
explanation: Approximating area under a curve by summing areas of trapezoids formed by ordinates at equal intervals.

name: length of an arc of a circle
explanation: Length of arc = r θ, where r is radius and θ is central angle in radians.

name: area of a sector of a circle
explanation: Area of sector = (1/2) r^2 θ, where r is radius and θ is central angle in radians.

name: volume of a prism
explanation: Volume = area of cross-sectional base × length.

name: surface area of a prism
explanation: Sum of areas of all faces of the prism, including two bases and lateral faces.

name: percentage error calculation
explanation: Percentage error = (absolute error / measured value) × 100%.

name: tolerance interval for measurements
explanation: Measurement tolerance is ± half the smallest unit of measurement scale.

name: powers and exponents
explanation: Raising a number to a power, representing repeated multiplication.

name: roots and radicals
explanation: Finding the root of a number, the inverse operation of powers.

name: constructing lengths using compass and straightedge
explanation: Geometric construction of lengths such as √2 or √3 on the number line using classical tools.

name: enlargement scale factor
explanation: The ratio by which all lengths in a figure are multiplied during an enlargement transformation.

name: centre of enlargement
explanation: A fixed point in the plane about which a figure is enlarged or reduced.

name: drawing an enlargement with a given centre and scale factor
explanation: Constructing the image of a figure by joining points to the centre of enlargement and marking points at distances scaled by the scale factor.

name: finding the centre of enlargement from a figure and its image
explanation: Locating the point where lines joining corresponding points of the object and image intersect, which is the centre of enlargement.

name: effect of scale factor on area
explanation: When a figure is enlarged by a scale factor k, its area is multiplied by k squared.

name: construction of a 60 degree angle using compass and straightedge
explanation: Using the properties of an equilateral triangle to construct a 60° angle with compass and straightedge.

name: construction of a tangent to a circle at a given point
explanation: Drawing a line perpendicular to the radius at the point on the circle to form the tangent.

name: construction of a parallelogram given side lengths and an angle
explanation: Using compass, straightedge, and protractor to construct a parallelogram with specified side lengths and included angle.

name: construction of the circumcircle of a triangle
explanation: Constructing the perpendicular bisectors of two sides of a triangle; their intersection is the circumcentre, the centre of the circumcircle passing through all vertices.

name: construction of the incircle of a triangle
explanation: Constructing the angle bisectors of two angles of a triangle; their intersection is the incentre, the centre of the incircle tangent to all sides.

name: construction of the centroid of a triangle
explanation: Constructing medians by joining each vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side; their intersection is the centroid.

name: construction of the orthocentre of a triangle
explanation: Constructing altitudes by drawing perpendiculars from each vertex to the opposite side; their intersection is the orthocentre.

name: properties of points on perpendicular bisector of a segment
explanation: Any point on the perpendicular bisector of a segment is equidistant from the segment's endpoints.

name: properties of points on angle bisector
explanation: Any point on the bisector of an angle is equidistant from the arms of the angle.

name: area of trapezium
explanation: Area equals half the sum of the lengths of the parallel sides multiplied by the height.

name: area of regular polygon using central angle and apothem
explanation: Area calculated by dividing the polygon into congruent triangles and summing their areas using trigonometric ratios.

name: area of sector of a circle
explanation: Area equals half the square of the radius multiplied by the central angle in radians.

name: length of arc of a circle
explanation: Length equals radius multiplied by the central angle in radians.

name: volume of prism
explanation: Volume equals the area of the base multiplied by the length (height) of the prism.

name: surface area of prism
explanation: Surface area equals twice the area of the base plus the perimeter of the base multiplied by the length.

name: volume of frustum of a cone
explanation: Volume equals the volume of the larger cone minus the volume of the smaller cone removed from the top.

name: percentage error and tolerance in measurement
explanation: Percentage error quantifies the relative error in measurement; tolerance is the allowable deviation based on measurement scale.

name: properties of similar figures under enlargement
explanation: Corresponding angles are equal and corresponding sides are proportional by the scale factor.

name: antidifferentiation of power functions
explanation: The process of finding the original function given its derivative, specifically for functions of the form x^n, by increasing the power by 1 and dividing by the new power.

name: integration of exponential functions with linear arguments
explanation: Integrating functions of the form e^(ax) by dividing by the coefficient a and adding the constant of integration.

name: integration of trigonometric functions with linear arguments
explanation: Integrating sine and cosine functions of the form sin(ax) and cos(ax) by dividing by the coefficient a and adjusting the sign accordingly.

name: area between two curves by integration
explanation: Finding the area of the region bounded by two curves by integrating the difference of their functions over the interval of intersection.

name: equation of tangent line to a curve at a point
explanation: Finding the equation of the tangent line to a curve at a given point using the derivative to find the slope and point-slope form of a line.

name: increasing and decreasing functions via first derivative test
explanation: Determining intervals where a function is increasing or decreasing by analyzing the sign of its first derivative.

name: finding stationary points by setting first derivative to zero
explanation: Locating points on a curve where the slope of the tangent is zero by solving f'(x) = 0.

name: second derivative test for classifying stationary points
explanation: Using the sign of the second derivative at stationary points to determine whether the point is a local maximum (negative), local minimum (positive), or inconclusive.

name: point of inflection and concavity change
explanation: A point on the curve where the concavity changes sign and the second derivative is zero, often where the tangent crosses the curve.

name: rate of change as derivative with respect to time
explanation: Interpreting derivatives as rates of change of quantities with respect to time, such as velocity as rate of change of displacement and acceleration as rate of change of velocity.

name: related rates problems using chain rule
explanation: Solving problems where two or more related quantities change with respect to time by differentiating implicit relations and applying the chain rule.

name: finding nth roots of complex numbers using de Moivre's theorem
explanation: Using polar form and de Moivre's theorem to find all nth roots of a complex number by dividing the argument by n and adding multiples of 2π/n.

name: multiplication and division of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: Multiplying moduli and adding arguments for multiplication; dividing moduli and subtracting arguments for division of complex numbers in polar form.

name: complex conjugate and its use in division
explanation: The complex conjugate of a + bi is a - bi; multiplying numerator and denominator by the conjugate rationalizes the denominator in division of complex numbers.

name: transformations of complex numbers by multiplication
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by a real number scales it; multiplying by i rotates it by 90 degrees counterclockwise in the complex plane.

name: translation of complex numbers by addition
explanation: Adding a complex number to another translates the point representing the number in the complex plane by the vector corresponding to the added number.

name: sample proportion
explanation: The fraction or percentage of a sample that has a particular attribute or characteristic, used as an estimate of the population proportion.

name: population proportion
explanation: The true proportion of a population that has a particular attribute or characteristic, often unknown and estimated by the sample proportion.

name: margin of error approximation for proportion
explanation: An approximate formula for the margin of error at 95% confidence level given by E = 1/√n, where n is the sample size.

name: confidence interval for population proportion using margin of error approximation
explanation: An interval estimate for the population proportion p given by sample proportion ± 1/√n at 95% confidence level.

name: standard error of sample proportion
explanation: The standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the sample proportion, estimated by sqrt(p(1-p)/n), where p is the population proportion and n is the sample size.

name: confidence interval for population proportion using standard error
explanation: A more accurate 95% confidence interval for population proportion p given by sample proportion ± 1.96 × sqrt(p(1-p)/n).

name: hypothesis testing for population proportion
explanation: A statistical method to test a claim about a population proportion by comparing the sample proportion and confidence interval or p-value at a given significance level.

name: null hypothesis for population proportion
explanation: The default assumption that the population proportion equals a specified value, tested against an alternative hypothesis.

name: alternative hypothesis for population proportion
explanation: The hypothesis that the population proportion differs from the value stated in the null hypothesis.

name: level of significance
explanation: The probability threshold (commonly 5%) below which the null hypothesis is rejected in hypothesis testing.

name: critical region and critical values
explanation: The set of values of the test statistic for which the null hypothesis is rejected; boundaries of this region are called critical values.

name: p-value in hypothesis testing
explanation: The probability of obtaining a test statistic as extreme as the observed one, used to decide whether to reject the null hypothesis.

name: sampling distribution of the mean
explanation: The probability distribution of sample means obtained from all possible samples of a fixed size from a population.

name: central limit theorem
explanation: The theorem stating that the sampling distribution of the sample mean approaches a normal distribution as sample size increases, regardless of the population distribution.

name: standard error of the mean
explanation: The standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the sample mean, given by population standard deviation divided by the square root of sample size.

name: z-score for sample mean
explanation: The number of standard errors that a sample mean is from the population mean, calculated as (sample mean - population mean) divided by standard error.

name: confidence interval for population mean with known standard deviation
explanation: An interval estimate for the population mean given by sample mean ± 1.96 × (population standard deviation / sqrt(sample size)) at 95% confidence level.

name: hypothesis testing for population mean
explanation: A statistical procedure to test a claim about a population mean using sample mean, population standard deviation, sample size, and significance level.

name: critical region for population mean test
explanation: The range of z-values beyond ±1.96 for which the null hypothesis about a population mean is rejected at the 5% significance level.

name: line of best fit
explanation: A straight line drawn through a scatter plot that best represents the trend of the data points.

name: correlation coefficient (Pearson's r)
explanation: A numerical measure of the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables, ranging from -1 to 1.

name: positive correlation
explanation: A relationship between two variables where as one increases, the other tends to increase.

name: negative correlation
explanation: A relationship between two variables where as one increases, the other tends to decrease.

name: no correlation
explanation: A situation where there is no apparent linear relationship between two variables.

name: causal relationship
explanation: A relationship where a change in one variable directly causes a change in another variable.

name: normal distribution
explanation: A continuous probability distribution characterized by a symmetric bell-shaped curve defined by its mean and standard deviation.

name: empirical rule for normal distribution
explanation: The rule that approximately 68% of data lie within 1 standard deviation, 95% within 2, and 99.7% within 3 standard deviations of the mean.

name: standard score (z-score)
explanation: The number of standard deviations a data point is from the mean, calculated as (x - mean) / standard deviation.

name: standard normal distribution
explanation: A normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 1, used as a reference for calculating probabilities.

name: normal probability distribution
explanation: A probability distribution for a continuous random variable that follows a normal distribution curve.

name: conversion from normal variable to standard normal variable
explanation: The process of converting a value x from a normal distribution with mean μ and standard deviation σ to a z-score using z = (x - μ) / σ.

name: probability from standard normal tables
explanation: Using standard normal distribution tables to find the probability that a standard normal variable Z is less than or equal to a given value.

name: probability between two z-scores
explanation: The probability that a standard normal variable lies between two values z1 and z2, found by subtracting cumulative probabilities.

name: exponential function
explanation: A function of the form f(x) = a^x where a > 0 and a ≠ 1, characterized by rapid growth or decay.

name: logarithmic function
explanation: The inverse function of an exponential function, defined as the logarithm base a of x, where a > 0 and a ≠ 1.

name: composition of functions
explanation: The operation of applying one function to the results of another function, denoted as (g ∘ f)(x) = g(f(x)).

name: inverse function
explanation: A function that reverses the effect of the original function, such that f⁻¹(f(x)) = x.

name: compound interest calculation with annual compounding
explanation: Calculating the amount of money accumulated after n years when interest is compounded once per year, using the formula F = P(1 + i)^t where P is principal, i is interest rate per annum, and t is number of years.

name: annual equivalent rate (AER) calculation from total return
explanation: Determining the equivalent annual interest rate that yields a given total return over multiple years, by solving (1 + i)^t = total return factor and extracting i.

name: monthly effective interest rate calculation from AER
explanation: Calculating the monthly interest rate r that compounds to a given annual equivalent rate i, using the relation (1 + r)^12 = 1 + i.

name: present value calculation for lump sum
explanation: Calculating the current worth of a future sum of money to be received after t years, discounted at an interest rate i, using Present Value = Future Value / (1 + i)^t.

name: reducing balance depreciation calculation
explanation: Calculating the depreciated value of an asset after t years when it loses a fixed percentage i of its value each year, using F = P(1 - i)^t.

name: instalment savings final value calculation
explanation: Calculating the accumulated value of regular equal payments P made at the beginning of each period for t periods at interest rate i per period, using F = P(1 + i)[(1 + i)^t - 1] / i.

name: pension present value calculation
explanation: Calculating the lump sum needed now to provide a fixed pension payment P at the end of each period for t periods at interest rate i, using PV = P / (1 + i) * [1 - (1 / (1 + i))^t] / [1 - 1 / (1 + i)].

name: loan or mortgage repayment calculation
explanation: Calculating the fixed periodic repayment A needed to repay a loan P over t periods at interest rate i per period, using A = P * [i(1 + i)^t] / [(1 + i)^t - 1].

name: perfect square trinomial
explanation: A quadratic expression that can be written as the square of a binomial, e.g., x^2 - 4x + 4 = (x - 2)^2.

name: axis of symmetry of a parabola
explanation: A vertical line through the turning point of a parabola that divides it into two mirror-image halves.

name: double root
explanation: A root of a polynomial where the graph touches but does not cross the x-axis, corresponding to a repeated factor.

name: binomial coefficient
explanation: The number of ways to choose r objects from n distinct objects, denoted as C(n, r) or n choose r.

name: Bernoulli trial
explanation: A random experiment with exactly two possible outcomes, success or failure, with fixed probabilities.

name: binomial distribution
explanation: The probability distribution of the number of successes in a fixed number of independent Bernoulli trials.

name: critical region
explanation: The set of values of a test statistic for which the null hypothesis is rejected in hypothesis testing.

name: critical value
explanation: The boundary value(s) of the critical region in hypothesis testing, often corresponding to significance levels.

name: p-value
explanation: The probability of obtaining a test statistic as extreme as the observed one, used to decide whether to reject the null hypothesis.

name: vertical line test
explanation: A graphical method to determine if a relation is a function by checking if any vertical line intersects the graph more than once.

name: horizontal line test
explanation: A graphical method to determine if a function is injective by checking if any horizontal line intersects the graph more than once.

name: injective function (one-to-one)
explanation: A function where each element of the codomain is mapped to by at most one element of the domain.

name: surjective function (onto)
explanation: A function where every element of the codomain is mapped to by at least one element of the domain.

name: bijective function
explanation: A function that is both injective and surjective, establishing a one-to-one correspondence between domain and codomain.

name: domain restriction
explanation: Limiting the domain of a function to make it injective and hence invertible.

name: empirical rule
explanation: The rule that approximately 68% of data lie within 1 standard deviation, 95% within 2, and 99.7% within 3 standard deviations of the mean in a normal distribution.

name: Types of functions (injective, surjective, bijective)

name: function as a unique output assignment

name: forming composite functions

name: graphing quadratic functions of the form ax² + bx + c with integer coefficients
explanation: Plotting graphs of quadratic functions where a, b, and c are integers and x is a real number.

name: graphing cubic functions of the form ax³ + bx² + cx + d with integer coefficients
explanation: Plotting graphs of cubic functions where a, b, c, and d are integers and x is a real number.

name: graphing exponential functions of the form ab^x with natural a and real b, x

name: using graphical methods to find approximate solutions to f(x) = 0

name: investigating the concept of the limit of a function
explanation: Exploring how function values approach a particular value as the input approaches some point.

name: recognising surjective functions
explanation: Identifying functions where every possible output value is mapped by at least one input value.

name: recognising injective functions
explanation: Identifying functions where each output value corresponds to at most one input value (one-to-one).

name: recognising bijective functions
explanation: Identifying functions that are both injective and surjective, establishing a one-to-one correspondence between inputs and outputs.

name: finding the inverse of a bijective function
explanation: Determining a function that reverses the effect of a bijective function, swapping inputs and outputs.

name: sketching the graph of the inverse function given the original function's graph

name: expressing quadratic functions in complete square form

name: using complete square form to find roots of quadratic functions

name: using complete square form to find turning points of quadratic functions
explanation: Using the vertex form to identify the maximum or minimum point of a quadratic function.

name: graphing quadratic functions with rational coefficients

name: graphing exponential functions with real coefficients
explanation: Plotting exponential functions where coefficients a and b are real numbers and x is real.

name: graphing logarithmic functions
explanation: Plotting functions that are the inverses of exponential functions, mapping multiplication into addition.

name: graphing trigonometric functions

name: informal exploration of limits and continuity of functions
explanation: Investigating how functions behave near points and whether they have breaks or jumps without formal epsilon-delta definitions.

name: finding first derivatives of linear functions by rule

name: finding first derivatives of quadratic functions by rule

name: finding first derivatives of cubic functions by rule

name: finding second derivatives of linear, quadratic, and cubic functions

name: associating derivatives with slopes and tangent lines

name: applying differentiation to rates of change
explanation: Using derivatives to calculate how quantities change with respect to one another.

name: applying differentiation to find maxima and minima
explanation: Using derivatives to locate points where functions reach local maximum or minimum values.

name: applying differentiation to curve sketching
explanation: Using derivatives to analyze function behavior such as increasing/decreasing intervals and concavity to sketch graphs.

name: differentiating polynomial functions
explanation: Applying differentiation rules to functions expressed as sums of powers of x with coefficients.

name: differentiating exponential functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of functions where the variable is in the exponent.

name: differentiating trigonometric functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of sine, cosine, and related functions.

name: differentiating functions with rational powers
explanation: Applying differentiation to functions where variables are raised to fractional exponents.

name: differentiating inverse functions
explanation: Finding derivatives of functions that reverse other functions.

name: differentiating logarithmic functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of logarithm functions.

name: differentiating sums, differences, products, quotients, and compositions of functions

name: using differentiation to find the slope of a tangent to a circle

name: first derivative of a linear function

name: first derivative of a quadratic function

name: first derivative of a cubic function
explanation: The derivative of a cubic function, resulting in a quadratic function that describes the slope of the tangent line at any point on the cubic curve.

name: second derivative of linear, quadratic and cubic functions
explanation: The derivative of the first derivative, indicating the rate of change of the slope, used to analyze concavity and points of inflection.

name: derivative from first principles
explanation: The definition of the derivative as the limit of the difference quotient, used to find the derivative of a function from its fundamental limit definition.

name: derivative of polynomial functions
explanation: Rules and methods to find derivatives of polynomial functions of any degree.

name: derivative of exponential functions

name: derivative of trigonometric functions
explanation: Finding derivatives of sine, cosine, and other trigonometric functions.

name: derivative of functions with rational powers
explanation: Finding derivatives of functions where the variable is raised to a rational exponent.

name: derivative of inverse functions

name: derivative of logarithmic functions

name: derivative of sums and differences of functions

name: derivative of product of functions
explanation: Using the product rule to find the derivative of the product of two functions.

name: derivative of quotient of functions
explanation: Using the quotient rule to find the derivative of the quotient of two functions.

name: derivative of composite functions
explanation: Using the chain rule to find the derivative of a composition of two or more functions.

name: application of differentiation to rates of change
explanation: Using derivatives to calculate how one quantity changes with respect to another, such as velocity as the rate of change of position.

name: application of differentiation to maxima and minima
explanation: Using derivatives to find local maximum and minimum values of functions by identifying critical points.

name: application of differentiation to curve sketching
explanation: Using first and second derivatives to analyze and sketch the shape of graphs, including identifying turning points and concavity.

name: finding slope of tangent to a circle using differentiation
explanation: Using differentiation to determine the slope of the tangent line at a point on a circle.

name: recognition of integration as reverse of differentiation
explanation: Understanding that integration is the inverse process of differentiation, recovering the original function from its derivative.

name: integration of sums, differences and constant multiples of functions
explanation: Applying linearity properties of integration to integrate sums, differences, and constant multiples of functions.

name: integration of power functions xa where a ∈ Q

name: integration of sine functions Sin(ax) where a ∈ R
explanation: Finding the integral of sine functions with real coefficients.

name: integration of cosine functions Cos(ax) where a ∈ R
explanation: Finding the integral of cosine functions with real coefficients.

name: finding area of plane regions bounded by polynomial curves
explanation: Using integration to calculate the area enclosed between polynomial function graphs and the x-axis or other curves.

name: finding area of plane regions bounded by exponential curves
explanation: Using integration to calculate the area enclosed between exponential function graphs and the x-axis or other curves.

name: informal exploration of limits of functions

name: informal exploration of continuity of functions

name: continuity of functions

name: Generating arithmetic expressions from repeating patterns

name: Representing relations with tables, diagrams, and graphs

name: Finding formulae for linear relationships

name: Identifying features of linear relationships

name: Representing linear relationships in tables, graphs, and formulas

name: Reasoning about rate of change and y-intercept in context
explanation: Interpreting the meaning of the slope (rate of change) and y-intercept within real-world situations and their representations.

name: Determining common values of two linear relationships
explanation: Finding points where two linear functions have the same output value, i.e., their intersection points.

name: Recognising and solving direct proportion problems
explanation: Identifying situations where two quantities vary directly and solving related problems using proportional reasoning.

name: Exploring graphs of motion quantitatively

name: Interpreting quantitative graphs and drawing conclusions

name: Describing quantity and change on graphs
explanation: Explaining both the amount and the rate at which quantities change as represented on graphs.

name: Evaluating algebraic expressions given variable values
explanation: Calculating the numerical value of expressions by substituting specific values for variables.

name: Expanding algebraic expressions
explanation: Using distributive property to multiply out brackets and rewrite expressions as sums or differences of terms.

name: Re-grouping algebraic expressions
explanation: Rearranging terms in expressions to group like terms together for simplification or further manipulation.

name: Factorising quadratic expressions
explanation: Expressing a quadratic polynomial as a product of two binomials or other factors.

name: Adding and subtracting linear and quadratic expressions
explanation: Performing addition and subtraction operations on expressions of the form ax + by + c and ax² + bx + c.

name: Simplifying expressions using associative and distributive properties
explanation: Applying associative and distributive laws to simplify complex algebraic expressions involving multiple terms and brackets.

name: Multiplying binomials

name: Rearranging formulae
explanation: Manipulating algebraic formulas to isolate a particular variable or express the formula in a different form.

name: Performing arithmetic operations on polynomials
